brief_summary: During Israel's occupation of Gaza Strip in November 1956 (part of Suez Crisis), Israeli Defense Forces conducted systematic screenings and executions in Khan Yunis and nearby Rafah. UNRWA officially documented 275 deaths in Khan Yunis and 111 in Rafah, though Palestinian sources estimate 520+ total deaths. Victims included refugees and civilians shot during curfew violations, mass screenings, and arbitrary detentions. Bodies were buried in mass graves. UNRWA Director submitted detailed victim lists and methods of killing to UN General Assembly.

commanders.name: Moshe Dayan
commanders.responsibility: Overall command of IDF operations during Suez Crisis including Operation Kadesh. Oversaw Gaza Strip occupation and screening procedures that led to mass killings in Khan Yunis and Rafah. Later Defense Minister (1967, 1969-74). Never prosecuted for 1956 Gaza operations.

commanders.name: David Ben-Gurion
commanders.responsibility: Ordered Operation Kadesh in coordination with France and UK during Suez Crisis. Authorized occupation of Gaza Strip. Made final decisions on military operations in Khan Yunis and Rafah. Oversaw policies during occupation period.

commanders.name: Moshe Carmel
commanders.responsibility: Commander of Israeli forces occupying Gaza Strip. Directly responsible for ground operations including screening procedures, curfews, and security operations in Khan Yunis and Rafah that resulted in mass civilian deaths.

commanders.name: Shimon Peres
commanders.responsibility: Key architect of Israel's alliance with France and UK for Suez operation. Facilitated military coordination. Later Prime Minister and President. Never faced accountability for role in 1956 Gaza operations.

executiveSummary.title: Executive Summary

alert.text: Historical context: Massacres occurred during brief Israeli occupation of Gaza (November 1956-March 1957) as part of coordinated attack with France and UK on Egypt during Suez Crisis.

paragraphs: In October-November 1956, Israel launched Operation Kadesh in coordination with France and the UK's invasion of Egypt during the Suez Crisis. Israeli forces rapidly occupied the Gaza Strip and Sinai Peninsula. During the occupation of Gaza, IDF conducted systematic 'screening' operations ostensibly to identify Egyptian soldiers and Palestinian fighters (fedayeen) who had infiltrated Israel.

On November 3, 1956, in Khan Yunis and its refugee camp, Israeli forces conducted mass roundups of male residents. During screenings, curfews, and arbitrary detentions, IDF personnel systematically executed civilians. UNRWA Director for Gaza Affairs compiled detailed victim lists and reported to UN General Assembly that 275 men were killed in Khan Yunis and 111 in nearby Rafah. Palestinian sources documented 415 killed with 57 missing. Methods included shooting during curfew, execution after screening, and arbitrary killings.

Bodies were buried in mass graves, including in the streets of Khan Yunis. UNRWA provided names, ages, and circumstances of death for verified victims. Despite international documentation and UN reports, no Israeli personnel were prosecuted. Israel withdrew from Gaza in March 1957 under international pressure, particularly from the United States and Soviet Union.

events.title: Operation Kadesh begins
events.description: Israel launches invasion of Sinai Peninsula in coordination with Franco-British attack on Egypt. Part of coordinated Suez Crisis military operations.

events.title: IDF occupies Gaza Strip
events.description: Israeli forces complete occupation of Gaza Strip and Khan Yunis. Begin imposing military administration and curfews.

events.title: Khan Yunis massacre begins
events.description: IDF conducts mass screenings of male residents in Khan Yunis and refugee camp. Systematic executions begin. Men rounded up for 'identification' of fedayeen and Egyptian soldiers.

events.title: Systematic killings
events.description: Over 10 days, IDF personnel shoot civilians during curfew, execute detainees after screenings, conduct arbitrary killings. Bodies buried in streets and mass graves. UNRWA documents 275 deaths in Khan Yunis.

events.title: Rafah massacre
events.description: Separate mass killing in nearby Rafah refugee camp. UNRWA documents 111 deaths. Similar pattern of screenings and executions.

events.title: UNRWA report submitted
events.description: UNRWA Director for Gaza Affairs submits detailed report to UN General Assembly (Document A/3512) documenting 275 deaths in Khan Yunis, 111 in Rafah, with names, ages, and circumstances.

sourceLinks.name: UN General Assembly Official Records - 11th Session

events.title: Israeli withdrawal
events.description: Under intense US and Soviet pressure, Israel withdraws from Gaza Strip and Sinai. UNEF (UN Emergency Force) deployed. No accountability for massacres.

alert.text: Content Warning: Documented systematic executions and mass killings of civilians.

crimes.title: Systematic Screenings and Executions
crimes.description: IDF conducted mass roundups of male residents for 'screening' to identify fedayeen and Egyptian soldiers. During and after screenings, soldiers systematically executed civilians. UNRWA documented names and circumstances of 275 killed in Khan Yunis alone.

crimes.title: Curfew Killings
crimes.description: Strict curfews imposed; civilians shot on sight for violations. Many killed for minor infractions or misunderstandings. UNRWA documented multiple cases of civilians shot during curfew hours.

crimes.title: Mass Graves
crimes.description: Bodies buried in mass graves including in streets of Khan Yunis. Hasty burials prevented proper identification of all victims. Some bodies left exposed for days as warnings.

crimes.title: Arbitrary Detentions and Killings
crimes.description: Mass arbitrary arrests during occupation. Detainees held without charge; many executed without trial or due process. No military tribunals or legal proceedings documented.

crimes.title: Collective Punishment
crimes.description: Entire neighborhoods and refugee camp subjected to collective punishment. Punitive measures included mass killings, curfews, house demolitions for suspected resistance or fedayeen activity.

international_law.title: International Law Violations
international_law.introduction: The Khan Yunis and Rafah massacres occurred under framework of Fourth Geneva Convention (1949), which Israel had ratified in 1951.

sections.heading: Fourth Geneva Convention (1949) Violations
violations: Article 3 (Common Article): Prohibits violence to life and person, murder, cruel treatment, torture. Systematic executions violated core protections even during armed conflict.
Article 27: Protected persons entitled to respect for persons, honor, family rights. Shall be protected against violence. Mass killings violated fundamental protections.
Article 32: Prohibited physical suffering or extermination of protected persons. Screenings followed by executions constituted extermination.
Article 147 (Grave Breaches): Willful killing of protected persons constitutes grave breach (war crime). Mass executions in Khan Yunis and Rafah were grave breaches.

sections.heading: Customary International Humanitarian Law
violations: Distinction principle: Failed to distinguish between combatants and civilians during screenings. Executed civilians arbitrarily.
Prohibition of arbitrary deprivation of liberty: Mass arbitrary detentions without due process violated customary law.
Prohibition of collective punishment: Entire populations of Khan Yunis and Rafah subjected to collective punishment for suspected fedayeen presence.

sections.heading: Modern Classification
violations: Under Rome Statute of International Criminal Court: acts would constitute crimes against humanity (murder, extermination) and war crimes (willful killing of protected persons, murder).
Systematic nature of killings over 10-day period suggests crimes against humanity element of widespread or systematic attack against civilian population.

alert.text: Accountability: Despite UNRWA documentation submitted to UN General Assembly with names of 386 victims (275 Khan Yunis, 111 Rafah), no Israeli personnel prosecuted. Military commanders later held senior government positions.

witnesses.name: UNRWA Director, Gaza Affairs
witnesses.testimony: Submitted detailed report to UN General Assembly December 15, 1956 (Document A/3512): 'During the period 3-12 November 1956, 275 persons were killed in Khan Yunis and its refugee camp.' Report included names, ages, circumstances of death compiled from credible witness accounts and physical evidence.
witnesses.source: UNRWA Special Report, UN GAOR 11th Session, Annexes, Agenda Item 66, Document A/3512

witnesses.name: Benny Morris
witnesses.testimony: In 'Israel's Border Wars 1949-1956': 'Israeli troops...massacred, apparently in cold blood, some 275 Palestinian civilians in Khan Yunis...and another 111 Palestinians in Rafah.' Based on Israeli military archives and UNRWA documentation. Confirmed systematic nature of killings.

witnesses.name: Avi Shlaim
witnesses.testimony: In 'The Iron Wall': 'In Khan Yunis and Rafah, IDF units committed what can only be described as war crimes.' Documented that killings occurred during screenings ostensibly to identify fedayeen but resulted in mass civilian deaths.
witnesses.source: 'The Iron Wall: Israel and the Arab World' (W.W. Norton, 2000)

witnesses.name: International Committee of the Red Cross
witnesses.testimony: ICRC delegates present in Gaza after Israeli withdrawal documented mass grave sites and interviewed survivors. Reports submitted to UN detailed systematic nature of killings and burial procedures.

witnesses.name: Palestinian Survivors
witnesses.testimony: Survivors described IDF soldiers rounding up men for 'identification checks,' taking them away, and returning without them. Bodies found later in mass graves. Families heard gunshots during screenings. Men shot for curfew violations or arbitrary reasons.
witnesses.source: Palestinian oral histories; documented by PCBS

sections.heading: Immediate Impact (1956-1957)
items: UNRWA submitted detailed documentation to UN General Assembly with victim names and circumstances
International attention focused on Suez Crisis; massacres received less scrutiny than Hungarian Revolution occurring simultaneously
US and Soviet pressure forced Israeli withdrawal from Gaza and Sinai by March 1957
UN Emergency Force (UNEF) deployed to Gaza; first major UN peacekeeping operation
No international calls for prosecution of perpetrators; Cold War dynamics prevented accountability

sections.heading: Long-term Significance
items: Pattern established: Israeli military operations in Gaza resulting in high civilian casualties without accountability
Khan Yunis massacre largely forgotten internationally; remains deeply embedded in Palestinian collective memory
Israeli historians (Morris, Shlaim) documented massacres decades later using declassified archives
Contributed to cycle of violence between Israel and Gaza Strip populations
Precedent for lack of accountability for mass killings of Palestinian civilians

sections.heading: Accountability Outcomes
items: ‚úó No Israeli military personnel prosecuted despite UNRWA documentation of 386 deaths
‚úó Military commanders (Moshe Dayan, Moshe Carmel) later held senior government positions
‚úó Victims' families never received compensation or official acknowledgment
‚úó Mass graves never properly excavated; many victims never formally identified

sources.title: Verified Sources & Documentation
sources.introduction: Primary sources include UNRWA official reports to UN General Assembly, contemporary witness accounts, and historical research based on UN archives and declassified Israeli military documents.

list.name: UNRWA Special Report to UN General Assembly (A/3512)
list.description: Official report by UNRWA Director, Gaza Affairs, December 15, 1956. Documented 275 deaths in Khan Yunis, 111 in Rafah with names, ages, circumstances. UN GAOR 11th Session, Annexes, Agenda Item 66.

list.name: UN General Assembly Official Records - 11th Session (1956-57)
list.description: Complete session documents containing UNRWA reports on 1956 Gaza occupation, Israeli operations, and civilian casualties during Suez Crisis period.

list.name: International Committee of the Red Cross - 1956-57 Gaza Reports
list.description: ICRC delegates present in Gaza after Israeli withdrawal. Documented mass grave discoveries, interviewed survivors, submitted reports to UN member states.

list.name: Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics - Historical Records
list.description: Palestinian official records documenting 415 killed plus 57 missing from Khan Yunis and Rafah massacres. Compiled from family reports, survivor testimonies, and documentary evidence.

list.name: Benny Morris - 'Israel's Border Wars 1949-1956' (Oxford, 1993)
list.description: Israeli historian's account based on declassified Israeli military archives. Confirms occupation operations and systematically documents 275 deaths in Khan Yunis, 111 in Rafah. Critical examination of IDF conduct.

list.name: Avi Shlaim - 'The Iron Wall' (W.W. Norton, 2000)
list.description: Oxford historian's comprehensive account of Israeli-Arab relations. Chapter on 1956 Suez Crisis discusses Khan Yunis and Rafah massacres based on UN documentation and Israeli sources.

list.description: Historical news reporting on Gaza occupation, Israeli operations, and initial reports of civilian casualties during Suez Crisis period.
